args: Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . Losing is the Wizards’ way. It might also be their way out. The Washington Wizards are in the middle of one of the worst seasons in NBA history. They won just nine of their first 54 games before the all-star break and have the worst record in the NBA, 3½ games behind the New Orleans Pelicans. The season extends the franchise’s struggles in the 21st century: The Wizards have the lowest winning percentage of all franchises since Jan. 1, 2000. They also haven’t won at least 50 games in a season — the mark of a very good but not great team — since 1978-79. The Wizards had been run by Ernie Grunfeld or his top lieutenant, Tommy Sheppard, since 2003. They broke away from that tree after the 2022-23 season in an organizational overhaul. Washington hired former Los Angeles Clippers general manager Michael Winger as the president of Monumental Basketball, the group overseeing the Wizards, the WNBA’s Washington Mystics and the G League’s Capital City Go-Go. Winger brought in General Manager Will Dawkins, who previously worked with Winger with the Oklahoma City Thunder. Weeks after the two were hired, they began an intense rebuild that included trading stars Bradley Beal and Kristaps Porzingis. An oversimplified description of Washington’s new strategy: Lose a lot, get high draft picks, accumulate young talent, and develop it into a winning core. The Wizards won just 15 games in 2023-24. They’re on pace for even fewer this season and have often lost by wide margins. Until recently, they were en route to having the worst average point differential in NBA history. A recent positive stretch (more on that later) has bumped them up to third worst. Winger and Dawkins have overseen two drafts in D.C. They have made four first-round picks, including three last year, and acquired another rookie this month in the Kyle Kuzma trade. The Wizards haven’t been shy about playing their youth, believing in-game repetitions — going through the fire, as Coach Brian Keefe often puts it — is the best way to develop. Injuries to Kuzma and guard Malcolm Brogdon early this season increased the young players’ minutes and roles. The development process often has been ugly — as evidenced by two 16-game losing streaks, each tying the franchise record. Washington almost always has multiple players on the court who have yet to reach their physical primes or maximize their skills — players who are often committing youthful mistakes and undergoing growing pains. The Wizards have the NBA’s worst offensive and defensive ratings (points scored and allowed per 100 possessions), per Basketball Reference. Those young players seem to be improving, an increased comfort somewhat evident in the Wizards’ recent positive stretch. In February, the team jumped to 11th in offensive rating and 21st in defensive rating, per analytics site Cleaning the Glass. The month even featured a season-best three-game winning streak. But Wizards fans probably don’t want to see their team win too much over the final 28 games. Though the NBA flattened the lottery odds so the three worst teams have the same chance at netting the No. 1 draft pick, finishing worst means that team can fall only as far as fifth. This season undoubtedly has been painful, evident in the red on all of these graphs. Winger, Dawkins and the rest of the organization hope the short-term struggles lead to a high draft pick and eventually the type of sustainable winner that has been absent in Washington for nearly 50 years.
